title: Can you help me understand Psalms 27:5-6? - Quora

response.answer_text: “For in the time of trouble he shall hide me in his pavilion: in the secret of his tabernacle shall he hide me; he shall set me up upon a rock. And now shall mine head be lifted up above mine enemies round about me: therefore will I offer in his tabernacle sacrifices of joy; I will sing, yea, I will sing praises unto the Lord.” God is always there to provide protection ONLY to those who do what he wants. “The LORD is good, a stronghold in the day of trouble: and he knoweth them that trust in him.” (Nahum 1:7). “The LORD is a sun and shield: the LORD will give grace and glory: No good thing will he hold from them that walk uprightly.” (Psalms 84:11). Your enemies can’t do anything to harm you. You’ll even be looking for them, and won’t find them. “For yet a little while, and the wicked shall not be: yea, thou shalt diligently consider his place, and it shall not be.” (Psalms 37:10). I recommend you watch this video because it helps you to understand how God can provide strength and protection for his righteous ones, and what we need to do in order to get his protection.

I think God is saying even in the midst of trouble, I’ve got you. There is a safe place within My heart for you, even when you are not safe at all in this world. In King David’s case, he was indeed granted military victory for Israel as well. That’s not the sort of thing we can all count on. I read and interesting Christian lecture on why some of the promises we like to believe are there for all of us were more specific to individuals or times in history. Nevertheless, in the New Testament, Paul, who lives a VERY unsafe life after his conversion, said whether we live or die, we belong to the Lord. Your enemies cannot have your soul if it belongs to God. We can all count on that.

In the preceding verse (vs.4) David is saying that the one thing he desires most is to dwell in God’s presence and to seek Him. He knows from experience that when he is close to the Lord and aware of His beauty and surrounding awesomeness, that he is protected and secure. Verses 2,3,5,6 speak of when trouble or danger comes, David is confident of the Lord’s help. Then in vs. 7 he is pleading with the Lord to continue being merciful and to answer him when he calls.

Although traditionally attributed to King David, there are repeated references to the temple, which was not supposed to even exist during the lifetime of David: ‘house of God’ (verse 4), ‘temple’ (verse 4), ‘pavilion’ (verse 5), ‘God’s tabernacle’ (verses 5, 6). All this means that the psalm was written either some time before the Babylonian Exile, or during the Persian period, after the temple had been rebuilt. Verses 2 and 3 implicitly refer to the Babylonian conquest and Babylon’s subsequent defeat (“stumbled and fell”), which helps date Psalm 27 to the Persian period. Psalm 27:5–6 attribute the return from Exile to the intervention of God, and express confidence that God will continue to protect the psalmist, concluding with praises to God.

Psalm 27:5-6 NLT 5 For he will conceal me there when troubles come; he will hide me in his sanctuary. He will place me out of reach on a high rock.6 Then I will hold my head high above my enemies who surround me. At his sanctuary I will offer sacrifices with shouts of joy, singing and praising the Lord with music. What don't you understand?

Temple, pavilion, tent… all refer to God's dwelling place. It was a real physical location in the OT and a place of sacrifice for sins of the people. Since sin is the dwelling place for tge enemy of God and our own souls, the temple would be a place of forgiveness from sin, thanksgiving and praise. It would then be a place where , in our minds we can rise above the grasp of sin and the enemy of our souls who would dwell there. Instead of animal sacrifice we can offer the sacrifice of praise. Jesus Christ was and is “the lamb of God” and the one and only worthy and effective sacrifice to remove our sin. We offer the sacrifice of praise through song and worship. It is through Christ the we, as the body of Christ, become the Temple and dwelling place for God.

The translation I use most often (NRSV) has ‘tent’ instead of ‘Temple’, but it makes no difference really. From the beginning of the psalm (and it is always best to look at the context of the passage you re trying to understand), the psalmist is speaking about being with the Lord, in the Lord’s house, and being safe from enemies. This psalm may have been written during one of the many times that Jerusalem was besieged. In any event, the psalmist finds safety in the Temple, in the Lord’s house, in the tabernacle, which is set high on a rock. And now the the psalmist can see his enemies and knows where they are, he feels safe and offers a sacrifice to God for his safety and protection.

In times of trouble he will shelter me; he will keep me safe in his Temple & make me secure on a high rock. So I will triumph over my enemies around me. With shouts of joy I will offer sacrifices in his Temple’ I will sing, I will praise the Lord. Heading is A Prayer of Praise God will take care of you through troubles. I will win over enemies. I will thank the Lord for his actions & sing.
